channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-11810] Access SSL Passwords through Credential Provider API
item.description:
HADOOP-10607 introduced the credential provider API for allowing passwords and other sensitive configuration items to be stored in an external provider.

RESTServer is accessing passwords stored in clear text in Configuration through the standard get() method. By using the new Configuration.getPassword method instead, the credential provider API will be checked first then fall back to clear text - when allowed.
item.summary: Access SSL Passwords through Credential Provider API

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Sounds good Larry McCay, do you intend to attach a patch? If so, it needs to work with older Hadoop 2.x versions that might be missing an API in newer 2.x.

hi Andrew Purtell - Yes, I will hopefully have a patch sometime early next week. I'm currently looking at the compatibility layer for the older Hadoop 2.x versions. I don't anticipate that being difficult though I am new to it.
The compatibility modules split the differences between Hadoop 1 and Hadoop 2. Differences intra Hadoop 2 will need reflection to deal with probably.

I've figured as much - it is a common pattern and others have already done it for this very usecase. So, it should be pretty easy to adapt for HBase. Both Hive and Accumulo have already done the same thing.

Both Hive and Accumulo have already done the same thing.

Great, looking forward to the patch. Thanks for thinking of us.

Is there any reason to not just use reflection in the HBaseConfiguration class to see whether the new getPassword method exists?
I'm thinking that we add a getHBasePassword to HBaseConfiguration and in it check whether Configuration.getPassword exists or not with reflection - if so invoke it otherwise fall back to plain ole get().

Is there a reason to do this in the compatibility layer instead?
What's odd is I don't see any use of reflection in there.

Larry, thanks for doing this work.
I think it is fine to do this using Reflection (as you described in your comment) to take care of the differences within the hadoop-2.x versions. I don't think we need to do this in the compatibility layer.

No the compatibility modules can't help differences intra major Hadoop release, so we have to use reflection instead. Ignore the compatibility modules. (We don't need reflection there because compile time differences are placed into respective maven modules e.g. if building for Hadoop 2 the Hadoop 1 compat module is not even selected for compilation)
Okay, great - thanks guys!
Okay, so, how do the unit tests work - do I need to write the provisioning of credentials through the API using reflection as well or do the unit tests only run against latest Hadoop?
Do write the tests using reflection as well..
Very good. Thanks Andrew Purtell!
Initial patch - enables HBaseConfiguration to provide passwords from credential provider API. Also adds to TestHBaseConfiguration.

+1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12664436/HBASE_11810.patch
against trunk revision .

This message is automatically generated.

Hi Andrew Purtell and Devaraj Das would either of you be able to review this patch and commit - if appropriate?
Thanks!

Patch lgtm.

I can test this with the latest branch-2? Let me try that and report back.

Yep - branch-2 should work.
Thanks!

On Thu, Aug 28, 2014 at 5:41 PM, Andrew Purtell (JIRA) <jira@apache.org>

Yep - branch-2 should work.

How do I know the reflective parts of the test engaged? I think some DEBUG level logging would be helpful. I will fix the log4j configuration problem wrt. unit tests in hbase-common right now, see HBASE-11856

Also, please don't do this even in a unit test:


+      } catch (Exception e1) {

+        e1.printStackTrace();

+      }

Log with WARN or ERROR logging level. Sorry I missed that on the previous skim.
Okay, Andrew Purtell - Just to be clear, you would like me to add DEBUG logging in HBaseConfiguration for both paths and replace the printStackTrace with logging in the test - correct?

Thanks Larry McCay, let me make a more specific request, hope that's clear: Please add DEBUG level logging in ReflectiveCredentialProviderClient that indicates the credential provider was loaded and instantiated successfully, and some logging that indicates the keystore was successfully consulted. It's a unit test so actually INFO level is fine too, whatever you prefer. And yes please don't print stack traces, send to them to log4j at WARN or ERROR level. Thanks!

Very good.
I have added DEBUG logging to HBaseConfiguration as well - let me know if you don't want that and I will remove it.
The rest is clear and should be done shortly.

This patches addresses Andrew's review comments and adds appropriate logging. Note that it indicates that the Configuration getPassword method is used or not. Can't really tell if getPassword falls back to config or what the underlying provider happens to be - but I think this meets your requirements.

Thanks! I tested the new unit test with 2.6.0-SNAPSHOT. Abbreviated test output:

2014-08-28 16:20:18,374 INFO  [main] hbase.TestHBaseConfiguration$ReflectiveCredentialProviderClient(201): Credential provider classes have been loaded and initialized successfully through reflection.

2014-08-28 16:20:18,715 WARN  [main] util.NativeCodeLoader(62): Unable to load native-hadoop library for your platform... using builtin-java classes where applicable

2014-08-28 16:20:19,129 DEBUG [main] hbase.HBaseConfiguration(183): Config option "ssl.keypass.alias" was found through the Configuration getPassword method.

2014-08-28 16:20:19,138 DEBUG [main] hbase.HBaseConfiguration(183): Config option "ssl.storepass.alias" was found through the Configuration getPassword method.



Tests run: 2, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 1.347 sec - in org.apache.hadoop.hbase.TestHBaseConfiguration



Results :



Tests run: 2, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0
Hey Andrew Purtell - I'm not seeing this patch committed anywhere - should I? Since the jira is marked as fixed - I expected to see it in the source tree.
Should be there now Larry, please check. See https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=hbase.git;a=log

Cool - it's there now.
Is there a different backend process for the actual commit in hbase than in
hadoop?
